== Towards a Generic Distributed Adaptive Hypermedia Environment ==
Hypertext has proven its value in many applications, including Technology-Enhanced Learning. Traditional paper textbooks present material in a single order, which is supposedly the best order for studying. In a hypertext, cross-references or links allow more freedom to navigate the material. An adaptive hypertext takes information about the reader into account when presenting the material including the cross-references. Actions taken by the reader (eg. following a link) can update the user model, hence change the adaptation.
Over the years many different adaptive hypermedia systems have been developed. These systems vary in the way the user is modelled and how that can affect the actual presentation. They are, for the most part, able to perform particular types of adaptation well, but are not compatible with each other. Furthermore, when compared to a traditional web server, an adaptive web server has more work to do. This has often led to performance issues, making the adoption of adaptive hypertext less likely.

In this thesis we present the current state of [[gale|GALE]], a generic Adaptive Hypermedia System (AHS). GALE is the result of its predecessor [[aha|AHA!]] and [[research|adaptive hypermedia research]]. It is a fully functional and extensible AHS. The various research [[research/projects|projects]] that enabled the development of AHA! and GALE, provided valuable input for the use cases of a generic AHS. Though we believe GALE is a feature-rich system, there are still ideas that require [[future-work|future work]].

Before diving into the full breadth and depth of the material, we recommend reading through the [[introduction]]. (We actually disable most of the content if you have not read the introduction, not just because we can.) It will give you a good idea of the [[questions]] that motivated the research and development described along the way. We provide a 'hyper'-adaptive page entitled '[[howitworks|How It Works]]'. This page will explain the inner workings of adaptivity as it is found in this thesis. The contents will change over time as your (presumed) knowledge on methods and techniques of adaptivity increase.
